description: [Status: stable] [Name: redundant-literal-union] [Message: Literal[{literal}] is redundant in a union with {builtin_type}] What it does Checks for redundant unions between a Literal and a builtin supertype of that Literal. Why is this bad? Using a Literal type in a union with its builtin supertype is redundant, as the supertype will be strictly more general than the Literal type. For example, Literal["A"] | str is equivalent to str, and Literal[1] | int is equivalent to int, as str and int are the supertypes of "A" and 1 respectively. Example from typing import Literal x: Literal["A", b"B"] | str Use instead: from typing import Literal x: Literal[b"B"] | str
